title: 105_hr734
content: The Patient Freedom of Choice Act of 1997, also known as the "Patient Freedom of Choice Act," requires notification of provider availability during the discharge planning process. The Patient Freedom of Choice Act of 1997 mandates that discharge plans under Medicare must not limit the provider for post-hospital care and must disclose any provider referrals made by the hospital. The Patient Freedom of Choice Act of 1997 requires hospitals to have a discharge planning process meeting specific requirements for individuals receiving medical assistance under Medicare. The Patient Freedom of Choice Act of 1997 mandates hospitals to comply with discharge planning requirements for Medicare beneficiaries, with penalties of up to $10,000 for non-compliance. The Patient Freedom of Choice Act of 1997 requires hospitals to follow discharge planning rules for Medicare patients, with penalties of up to $10,000 for each violation. The amendments in the Act will be effective 90 days after its enactment, applying to discharges, hospital services expenditures, failures, and violations occurring after that date. SEC. 3. MAINTENANCE AND DISCLOSURE OF INFORMATION ON POST-HOSPITAL SERVICE PROVIDERS. Medicare Requirement amended to include hospitals with financial interests in post-hospital service providers to disclose nature of financial interest to the Secretary. The Medicare Requirement now includes hospitals disclosing financial interests in post-hospital service providers to the Secretary, along with details on discharged individuals and services provided. The Secretary will make public certain hospital financial interest and referral pattern information as required by the Medicare Requirement. Regulations for these amendments must be issued within one year of the enactment of the Act.
